bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to J.W. Amesse, August 5, 1908

div1.p: Kean suggests that a case of yellow fever was contracted not in Santiago di Cuba but in Daiquiri.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to J.W. Amesse, August 5, 1908
div1.p:
Believing that it will be of interest to you, I send you a
copy of the report of Major Ogden Rafferty, Medical Corps, U. S.
Army, in the case of Ramón Gómez who was found with yellow fever
on the S. S. Julia in the port of San Juan on July 5th. The clini-
cal report attached was kindly furnished to Maj. Rafferty by the
quarantine officer, Dr. Foster. Attached is also a copy of a
telegram from Capt. H. D. Thomason, Medical Corps, U. S. Army,
Special Commissioner of the Sanitary Department at Santiago.

You will observe that there is an apparent conflict between
the statements made by Ramón Gómez to Maj. Rafferty that he stay-
ed only one night in Santiago and the entry on the register of
the fonda La Union in Santiago showing that he was there on the
29th. Of course it is possible that he stayed two nights instead
of one in Santiago, and it is also equally possible, and I think
more probable, that the people at the fonda may have failed to
put in the new date of June 30th, and allowed a guest to register
under the date of the day before. It is also entirely possible
that his attack began before July 4th as we constantly find to
happen in the case of Spaniards in whom the first symptoms are
not very severe and especially when they are sea-sick. Even,
however, if all suppositions are rejected which shorten the
period between his leaving Daiquirí and his being sick from
the afternoon of the 29th to the afternoon of the 4th is 5 days which
2-Dr. J.W.A.
gives a day to spare for the possible incubation period for
him to have contracted the disease at Daiquirí. As he stayed
in Daiquirí in a focus of active infection and no case of fever
has occurred in the locality where he stayed in Santiago, all
the non-immunes there being under daily inspection, it seems
to me that the inference is inevitable that the disease was
contracted in Daiquirí

I would suggest that after looking over these papers, you
forward them to your Department in Washington.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Kean
Adviser to Sanitary Department. Dr. J. W. Amesse,
Past Asst. Surgeon,
P. H. & H. H. Service,
U.S. Quarantine Office,
Machina Wharf.
